files.title: Center of Excellence
files.name: Corporate Banking
files.description: Corporate banking is defined as custom-tailored financing and banking services for corporations. Corporate banking, also known as business banking, refers to the aspect of banking that deals with corporate customers Corporate banking is typically offered by commercial banks, and entails all the services that can be extended on a financial level to corporate entities to ease day-to-day operations.

files.title: What is Corporate Banking ?
files.name: Corporate Banking
files.description: Corporate banking is defined as custom-tailored financing and banking services for corporations. Corporate banking, also known as business banking, refers to the aspect of banking that deals with corporate customers Corporate banking is typically offered by commercial banks, and entails all the services that can be extended on a financial level to corporate entities to ease day-to-day operations.

files.name: Corporate Banking-Functional Diagram
files.title: Corporate Banking

files.name: Products & Services Offered
files.title: Corporate Banking
files.description:
• Loans and other credit products
  • Treasury and cash management services
  • Equipment lending
  • Commercial real estate
  • Trade finance
  • Employer services

files.name: Loans and other credit products
files.title: Products & Services Offered
files.description: This is typically the biggest area of business within corporate banking, and as noted earlier, one of the biggest sources of profit and risk for a bank.

files.name: Treasury and Cash Management Services
files.title: Products & Services Offered
files.description: Used by companies for managing their working capital and currency conversion requirements

files.name: Equipment Lending
files.title: Products & Services Offered
files.description: Commercial banks structure customized loans and leases for a range of equipment used by companies in diverse sectors such as manufacturing, transportation and information technology.

files.name: Commercial Real Estate
files.title: Products & Services Offered
files.description: Services offered by banks in this area include real asset analysis, portfolio evaluation, and debt and equity structuring.

files.name: Trade Finance
files.title: Products & Services Offered
files.description: Involves letters of credit, bill collection and factoring.

files.name: Employer Services
files.title: Products & Services Offered
files.description: Services such as payroll and group retirement plans are typically offered by specialized affiliates of a bank.

files.title: Corporate Banking
files.description:

  • Wells Fargo.
  • Bank of America.
  • Citigroup.
  • U.S. Bancorp.

files.title: Center of Excellence
files.name: Institutional Banking
files.description: Institutional Banking is a specialized division within a bank that offers a comprehensive suite of products and services for large institutions both locally and abroad. In particular they can provide complex financing and advisory functions for corporate and government clients who may require tailored capital products.

files.name: What is Institutional Banking?
files.title: Institutional Banking
files.description: Institutional Banking is a specialized division within a bank that offers a comprehensive suite of products and services for large institutions both locally and abroad. In particular they can provide complex financing and advisory functions for corporate and government clients who may require tailored capital products.

files.name: Example of Institutional Banking
files.title: Institutional Banking
files.description: Institutional banking usually incorporates services such as evaluating mergers & acquisitions, investments and divestments, managing treasuries etc. Institutional banking helps clients to create corporate strategies and develop opportunities for growth on a national and global level. Institutional banking provides clients with expertise, research analysis and result-based methodologies that enable them to make sound financial decisions, suited to their business environment

files.name: Major Corporate Banks across the globe

  • Goldman Sachs.
  • Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
  • Morgan Stanley.
  • Citi Group
  • Credit Suisse.
  • Barclays Investment Bank.
  • Deutsche Bank.

files.title: Center of Excellence
files.name: Retail Banking
files.description: Retail banking also known as Consumer Banking is the provision of services by a bank to individual consumers, rather than to companies, corporations or other banks.

files.name: What is Retail Banking
files.title: Retail Banking
files.description: Retail banking also known as Consumer Banking is the provision of services by a bank to individual consumers, rather than to companies, corporations or other banks.

1. Saving Accounts
  2. Current Accounts

  2. Loans – Mortgages, Personal, Studies, Vehicles etc.,
  3. Debit cards

  5. Safe deposit vaults/lockers

files.name: Risk Analytics (RA)
files.title: Center of Excellence
files.description: It is the study of the underlying uncertainty of a given course of action. By using analytics to measure, quantify, and predict risk, leaders can rely less on intuition and create a consistent methodology steeped in data-driven insights

files.name: What is Risk Analytics
files.title: Risk Analytics
files.description: It is the study of the underlying uncertainty of a given course of action. By using analytics to measure, quantify, and predict risk, leaders can rely less on intuition and create a consistent methodology steeped in data-driven insights

files.name: What is Risk Management?
files.title: Risk Management
files.description: Risk Management is the Identification, Analysis and Economic Control of those risks which can threaten the Assets (Property, Human) or the earning Capacity of an Enterprise.

files.name: Types of Risk
files.title: Risk
files.description:
• Operational Risk
  • Credit Risk
  • Market Risk
  • Business Event Risk
  • Inflation Risk
  • Liquidity Risk
  • Political Risk
  • Reinvestment Risk

files.name: Credit Risk
files.title: Types of Risk
files.description:
• When there is a counterparty failure in performing the repayment obligation on due date, it gives rise to credit risk.
  • Credit risk is inherent part of any firm that is into business of lending funds.

files.name: Market Risk
files.title: Types of Risk
files.description:
• Market risk is the risk of value of a firm’s investment going down as a result of market movement. It is also referred as price risk or systematic risk
  • Market risk cannot be distinctly separate from other risk. It results from interplay of other risks
  • Interest rate risk and exchange rate risk contribute the most to the presence of marker risk.

files.name: Operational Risk
files.title: Types of Risk
files.description:
• This risk results from inadequate or failed internal processes/people/systems or from external events
  • Operational risk can be summarized as human risk; it is the risk of business operations failing due to human error. Operational risk will change from industry to industry, and is an important consideration to make when looking at potential investment decisions. Industries with lower human interaction are likely to have lower operational risk
